author: E-mail: crimescene@nytimes.com Twitter: @mwilsonnyt
body: ''I would know it,'' Esther Davis told me back in May, a few days after thieves had made off with her wrought-iron gate that squeaked open and shut on Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn for almost all of her 53 years. Adding to her frustrations was the fact that the thieves stole a bunch of gates that day; she was one of many victims standing in front
title: CRIME SCENE; Diverging Paths of Victims Can Run Into Dead Ends

body: NEXT week the large-ensemble jazz composer Darcy James Argue and the graphic novelist Danijel Zezelj will be collaborating for four nights on ''Brooklyn Babylon,'' as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is an hourlong performance involving an 18-piece band conducted by Mr. Argue, with nearly continuous animation and
title: Animation Joins Jazz At the Next Wave Festival

body: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the city's next great destination for bargains. Despite this well-worn path off the island, however, finding a place to live in some up-and-coming corner of the city can have its
title: Step Away From the Computer

body: Tropical Storm Irene moved through New York City on Sunday knocking out power, causing flooding in some neighborhoods and knocking over many trees. In one corner of Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, the storm also set off a fight -- over bees. In a gale wind from the storm, a hollowed-out branch of an enormous tree was ripped off, exposing a hive of
title: In Rescue of Beehive Exposed by High Winds, Honey and Rancor

body: IT was the duck rillettes that led Steve Rosenbush to Laura Hwang. Mr. Rosenbush walked into Blue Apron Foods in Park Slope, Brooklyn, just before closing time in March 2006, looking for some of this pâté-like treat. As he approached the checkout counter, he noticed a beautiful young cashier with a vibrant smile and easy grace. ''I was
title: VOWS; Laura Hwang and Steve Rosenbush

body: Lefferts Gardens Row House $1,600,000 BROOKLYN: 51 Midwood Street (between Flatbush and Bedford Avenues)A six-bedroom two-and-a-half-bath 1898 Lefferts Manor limestone house with an office and a landscaped garden. Susan Slater, Corcoran Group (917) 744-1454; www.corcoran.com Open house June 12, 1 to 3 p.m.TAXES: $4,832 a yearPROS: The parlor floor,
title: ON THE MARKETS

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum (Friday) The Primavera Consort will play music of the Baroque period, with works by Vivaldi, Telemann, Handel and Bach; at 7 p.m. Reservations are requested: (718) 885-1461. 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx , bartowpellmansionmuseum.org; $8, $5 for 65+ and students, and free
title: Spare Times

body: A shop in the Prospect-Lefferts Gardens neighborhood in Brooklyn has gained a large following with its offerings of ital food and vegetarian ice cream.
title: Neighborhood Joint | Scoops

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: In the summer of 2009, city officials began a $20 million program that would allow developers to convert stalled condominium sites into moderate-income housing. The initial response was tepid, as many developers and investors clung to the hope that the New York housing market would rebound. Now, nearly two years later, the city has closed on its
title: Deal on Stalled Condo Project Is First Under a City Program

body: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and ''we took up the entire basement,'' Mr. Alvarez said. Somehow they had accumulated an array of space-hogging clothes,
title: THE HUNT; A Move Dictated by Miscellany
